item.title: Accounting
item.description:
The sales or revenue is also called the top line of a company
Accounting merely means recounting; and this process involves recording, classifying and summarizing of past events and transactions of financial nature with a view to enabling the user of accounts to interpret the resulting summary
Quote “This planet has—or rather had—a problem, which was this: most of the people living on it were unhappy for pretty much of the time. Many solutions were suggested for this problem, but most of these were largely concerned with the movement of small green pieces of paper, which was odd because on the whole it wasn't the small green pieces of paper that were unhappy.” — Douglas Adams


Inflow - Income (money coming in that isn't repayable), Debt/Liabilities (money coming in that is repayable), Selling Asset
Outflow - Expense (Something you're spending money on that you are getting the rewards of instantly, you don't get the money back), Assets (Something you're spending money on that you will get rewards of in long term and you get the money back - recoverable, whatever a firm holds and uses for a long period), Clearing Liability
Classification of transactions happens in these 6 areas ^
Income - Not repayable inflow
Liability - Repayable inflow
Expense - Not recoverable outflow
Assets - Recoverable in the future
Profit and loss is , P&L account deals with revenue
Balance sheet is in liabilities and assets, BL sheet deals with capital
To account for asset usage, depreciation cost is kept in expenses
Depreciation is a non cash expense


Tangible - Land, plant, machinery, etc.
Intangible - Goodwill, etc.
Whatever is payable is a liability, whatever is receivable is an asset
Whatever you use for a long period of time is also an asset


You buy a machine and depreciate it to 0 over 5 years in the machinery account, when you sell it, you log it as: income
If the machine breaks down before depreciation makes it 0, you file the rest as expense


Is an earning as a result of normal business activity or otherwise. It is also called sales turnover
Whatever is from the main core of the business is operating income


An expense is an outflow of money in return for a product or service. It is also known as cost


An asset is a resource which has economic usefulness in business operations over several years


A liability is an obligation owed by the business to any external stakeholder
Every transaction has atleast 2 effects in 1 or more of these 4 buckets
HW - ask about the number of accounts
HW - How many accounts would I have?


business owner and business are separate entities

the profits minus dividends are shown as a liability to the owner


each company is an ongoing operation - accounting is to be done with the idea that the company will never close down


Every transaction needs monetary term - no bartering


In the books of accounting, everything is accounted for at historical costs only
No notional or market values


whatever you're earning has to be matched - P&L is accurately depicted


Accounting for things in the right period


you will account for a transaction even if actual cash isn't coming in
If it's coming in then account for it for sure
receivables are accounted for when they are accounted for not when they aren't
Treat every transaction in isolation
receivable account exists brother


anything that is significant enough for decision making should be disclosed separately
If any transaction is above a certain threshold, it has to be shown separately in the reports - the thresholds are set by the companies act
Some classifications have to be disclosed separately even if they aren't above the thresholds set by the companies act
any major event has to be disclosed


there are accounting standards - international, indian, etc.
bunch of rules that tell you how to account for different stuff
Although you are free to choose a standard, stick with it


You cannot record for a notional or forseeable profit but you must record for forseeable losses
Basically if you're happy, stop being happy because accounting doesn't want that
inventory is products unsold by the end of the year - matching principle says what didn't get sold cannot be taken as an expense. inventory is an asset
inventory is to be valued at market value or net realizable value, whichever is lower - exception to cost principle
Todo Prepare your own balance sheet and your own P and L
be




Revenue expenditure is everything that is expense - whatever is used for day to day operations


When the benefits of the expenditure is not exhausted in the year in which it was incurred
An example of expenditures incurred is in purchase of fixed assets
Faq Assets that aren't fixed assets:
Inventory
Short term loans These are called current assets


Proprietor - the person who invests his money in the business and bears all risks connected with the business is called the proprietor
Capital - It means amount invested by the proprietor in the business. For the business, capital is a liability towards the owner.
Drawings - It is the amount of money taken away by the proprietor for personal use


Debtor is someone who owns money to you - usually someone you've sold goods on credit
Other terms for debtor are - receivables, trade receivables, account receivables
Creditor is the person from whom the company has a debt from. Generally the vendor from whom they've bought stuff on credit
Payables, trade payables, accounts payables
Debtor is asset and creditor is liability


Goods - Purchased for resale or to produce finished products which are also meant to be sold
What the company trades or manufactures
Companies can be classified broadly into companies that sell goods and companies that sell services
In goods, companies can be classified into traders and manufacturers
There'll be a purchase account for all the inward movement of goods and a sales account for the outward movement of goods Hint The purchase account is expense, the other effect of purchase is cash (goes down)
The expense account is income and the other effect is cash (goes up) whatever you haven't sold at the end of the accounting period, is called the closing stock, whatever is in closing stock, in the next accounting period, becomes the opening stock "When you're buying, its expense, when you're selling it's sales, jo bachgaya hai, becomes inventory" Inventory isn't a transaction, but since you own it, it's an asset
Returns - Accounted as sales returns, when the customer doesn't like your stuff
Return inward
Return from you - accounted as purchase return, when you don'tlike your suppliers stuff
Return Outward
Goods which are in the transition stage if the processing time is high is called "work in progress"


Solvent - A person who is in a position to pay his debts as they become due
Insolvent - A person who is not in a position to pay his debts as they become due
When a customer doesn't have enough money to pay their dues, they are declared insolvent, you must write off this asset, call it bad debt. Non performing asset
If, later on the customer gives the money, you account it as an income
Following the principle of conservatism, companies are required to keep a provision for "doubtful" debts


Wages is what is paid to the blue collar staff and salary is what is paid to the white collar staff
Losses are something against which the business receives no benefit
Profit -> Income-Expenses

Say soma starts a tea stall, he brings in 1000 rupees and borrows 1000 rupees. It is borrowed on the condition that at the end of every month he will have to pay 300 rupees. That's all he can borrow at the present Soma starts with 2000 rupees. Total capital employed is 1000 rupees (owner's funds/ shareholders funds) and 1000 rupees of borrowed money (debt/borrowings) Hot plate, vessels, crockery, etc is bought by soma for 1000 rupees. These are fixed assets. Then He buys his raw material like tea, milk, etc. These are his stock/inventory of working capital for 500 rupees. 500 rupees is left On day 1 he sells 100 cups of tea at 5 rupees each. The tradition in the area is that you're paid the next day. Soma hasn't received a single rupee yet but he knows he will receive tomorrow(accounts receivable) He is left with 200 rupees worth of stock which is usable on the next day He has hired a helper wjo will cost him 50 rupees a day. The helpers salary will be paid on a weekly basis. Besides,he has to pay 10 rupees as interest on the loan Soma has not recieved a single penny at the end of day 1, but we know that he generated sales of 500 rupees and material cost was only 300 rupees. In other words,his gross profit was 200 rupees. Sales-direct revenue expenditure = gross profit We are taking into account sales and expenses only without any cash coming in, this is called the accrual principle Consider material cost on day 1. Logically,we take material cost at 300 rupees If soma has to close his business the next day, his fixed assets will barely sell for 200 rupees, so do we take this as a loss of 800 rupees? no cus going converna and all so we gotta keep positive If at the end of the day someone promises you that he will buy 200 cups at 6 rupees, you cant mark that as a profit cus conservatism Copy


Fixed assets- form the productive capacity for any business and are not traded in the course of the business
Current assets - the ones that will get converted into cash within a regular operator cycle
Current liabilities - are liabilities expected to e paid in cash in normal business cycle


Refer to ppt


Nominal accounts - all accounts related to income or expenses
Real accounts - Anything that can be owned - only fixed assets EVERYTHINGGGGGG OH YEAHHHHH
Personal accounts - personal account, related to an entity, like bank account, customer account, vendor account, loan taken from a bank. They are personal accounts since they represent an entity, they can be assets or liabilities
Jaise sales is nomial account, customer is personal account,
Golden matrix (refer to ppt)
Cash and stock are real and bank and debtors are personal
Liabilities are all personal since they are all related directly to an entity

Quote "Whatever notions you have about debit and credit, please maro CTR+ALT+DELETE"

For personal account, treating every transaction in isolation, in a particular transaction, debit the receiver, credit the giver
For real account, debit what comes in, credit what goes out
For nominal account, debit all expenses and losses, credit all incomes and gains Example cash sales - sales and cash accounts. Sales is nominal, cash is real. Sales mein credit, cash mein debit
debit and credit are only accounting operators


STep 1 - identify the accounts affected
STep 2 - for each account, identify the type (real, nominal, personal)
STep 3 - ask the appropriate question based on the type (questions given above) to register it as credit or debit Done Up till here in the presentation

item.title: Agastya's solution
item.description:
Important Agastya appreciation note for actually trying to solve this problem, when I disregarded it
If I had more time, I'd run a gradient descent or genetic algorithm on the guess parameters to better find the global minimum. I enjoy sleep so I avoided that - heres the solution. Pretty simple but feels weird to make a CSTR a constraint :/
Info The gauss seidel solver is an early implementation, primarily because I didn't know it was gauss seidel. The idea was just some jugaad method of getting rate of R to get the space time to get the volume of the reactor given the constraints. It was pointed out to me by a professor that I was simply solving a system of linear equations later on. Apologies to the applied math 2 professor for not remembering gauss seidel. The engineer in me just likes jugaad For similar problems, I suggest using a standard algorithm for gauss seidel and proper definition of the equations involved. Also the last part regarding the guess params can be improved, for any ML engineers here, please help find the global minimum in the most sophisticated manner

# Modify this for any backmix system or mixed flow model with any number of reactions occurring def func2(guess_params): def func(x): a,b = x[0],x[1] # Making sure the parameters being minimized don't break physics if any(value < 0 for value in x): return float('inf') if (0.1*a-100)<0 or (0.1*b-100)<0: return float('inf') # Gauss seidel guess values RateR = 100/(a+b) rateS=0.01 space_time = 1 # Gauss seidel iteration below for i in range(1000): rateS = 34.4*((0.1*b-100-2*rateS*(a+b)*space_time)**2)/((a+b)**2) rateR = (68.8*(0.1*a-100)*(0.1*b-100-2*rateS*(a+b)*space_time))/((a+b)**2) space_time = 100/((a+b)*rateR) Volume = space_time*(a+b) # Just to be sure we aren't minimizing below 0 for cost if (0.5*a*0.1+0.5*b*0.1+Volume*0.01) <0 or rateR<0 or rateS<0: return float('inf') return (0.5*a*0.1+0.5*b*0.1+Volume*0.01) # Initial guess for the parametersds x0 = guess_params from scipy.optimize import minimize # Minimize the function result = minimize(func, x0, method='Nelder-Mead') # Print the minimized values print("Minimized values:", result.x) print(func(result.x)) return result.x # The below is just to be sure that the gradient descent doesnt end up finding a local minimum from random import randint pms = [1700,1100] for i in range(20): pms = func2([pms[0]+(randint(0,100)-50),pms[1]+(randint(0,100)-50)]) Copy

item.title: Bhopal Accident
item.description:
#safety
#safety * After Bhopal incident, the process safety subject had a wake up call

Lots of loss of life and property and the accident should never have happened
Methyl isocyanate gas leaked and caused havoc. It's a very toxic gas
There is a reaction - monomethyl amine+phosgene -> MIC, MIC+ alpha napthil -> carbaryl.
Union carbide put up a plant in india in the 30s. After 1980, the company started making the MIC onsite
There were three MIC tanks, T1,T2 and T3, which was a spare tank. Each tank had a cooling jacket, water curtain. There was a scrubber and there was a flare. each tank had a pressure gauge, temperature sensor and level indicator
Scrubber is an absorber, is any MIC escapes, the scrubber will absorb it. If anything escapes the scrubber, it goes to the flare
2nd december 1984, the night time, it was winters. When a pollutant enters atomosphere, the winds determine how far they'll go. If the winds flow at high speed, it will go very far away. An operator noticed a leak, he thought it was fine. Supervisor, an hour later, told the operator to check the piping and the valve. The valve had a leak. Another half an hour later, more smell came. The operator found the temp and pressure in the tank to be higher than usual. He thought it was due to gas being discharged by the people on the previous shift.
A lot of time passed, they finally realized the weight of the problem. By then water came in contact with MIC and a vigorous runaway reaction started. On this day, no refrigeration unit working, water curtain malfunctioned, people forgot about T3, scrubber was out of service and flare was under repair
The MIC escaped, the plant was near the railway station in the city and the gas was spread all over the city and people got irritated and there was no escape for them.
Shift supervisor asked operator to wash the leak to find the leak. This is how water could have come into the stream.


Adequate in built safety systems were not provided and those provided were not well maintained
Safe operating procedures (SOP) were not laid down and followed under strict supervision
Total lack of onsite and offsite emergency control measures
no hazard and operability study was carried out on the design
evacuation drills were not held and practiced
The community living near the plant were never warned about the dangers
The local authorities weren't informed of the hazards and this couldn't respond effectively
Signals were ignored


Dr Trevor Kletz rightly says, "What you don't have, you cant leak"
Wherever and whenever possible reduce the inventories of hazardous materials
Instead of making dangerous intermediaries, use a different paths
People who are not there, cannot be killed, build factories outside of city limits
HAZOP should be carried out
Keep protective instruments in proper order and proper size
Safe operating procedures must be maintained on a regular schedule
Training in loss prevention - loss prevention is an integral part of design, hazards should be removed in design instead of adding protective equipment
Handling in offsite and onsite emergencies - a well planned and monitored "on site" emergency control plan is the responsibility of the individual industry and off site should be planned by the local authorities.

item.title: Bio-safety
item.description:
#safety
#safety Bio related work involves manipulation of microbial, animal or plant cells

Risks associated with these activities arise from the samples
Use facilities suitable with the risk level of pathogen. BS-4 people are madlads


hazards related with the pathogen or human/animal cells being used in research
related with the procedures and practices followed in tha lab
researchers who manipulate human/animal cells are at risk of possible exposure to potentially infectious pathogens that may be present in those cells/tissues
human cell lunes may contain blood borne pathogens which can be transmitted due to improper handling
Inhalation of aerosols
Contact of the agent with the skin, eyes or mucus membrane
Inocculation by contaminated drugs
Bites from infected animals or contact with their body fluids

can be generated when:
pipetting
Blending
Centrifugation
Sonication
These respirable size particles when inhaled are retained in the lungs and cause infection


Risk group 1 - won't cause any infection in humans/animals. Least risky
Risk group 2 - can cause disease in humans/animals but won't be a serious hazard like ecoli and all
Risk group 3 - A pathogen that can cause serious animal or human disease but wont spread. Foot and mouth disease virus
Risk group 4 - pathogen that usually causes serious human or animal disease and can be readily transmitted from one individual to another

any combination of vector and host must be chosen to limit the the infectivity of vector to specific hosts and control the host vector survival in the environment

Polar dissolves polar, light dissolves light


This is a sensor for gas chromatography. The analyte goes into the flame and is ionized.
When sample goes into the flame the flow rate is very low, to avoid the broadness of the peak.
A small current is produced which can be measured and create a chromatogram.
FID is a specific property detector with characteristic high sensitivity


A plot of the detectors response as a function of the elution time is a chromatogram
Retention time is the time between the samples injection and the maximum response
How to know which peak is what? Use standard solutions to know the standard retention time. SO push each chemical in separately

item.title: Electrical Safety
item.description:
#safety
#safety
Static electric discharge causes fire
Questions

Static electricity causes events Example A fire and a series of explosions occurred in a chemical distribution facility. The fire started in a packaging area while a 300 gallon tank was being filled with ethyl acetate. An operator place the fill nozzle in the opening on the top of the tank and suspended a steel veil on it to keep it in place. As the tank was filling the operator heard a popping sound and saw it engulfed in flames. The nozzle was laying on the floor spilling ethyl acetate. Employees tried unsuccessfully to extinguish the fire, couldnt do so. The are was evacuated. The fire spread to a warehouse igniting other stored liquids. Because of the smoke and the rocketing barrels, nearby businesses were evacuated.
It was determined that an ignitable vapour air mixture formed near the tote fill opening. While the body of the tank, the weigh scale and the pump were grounded. The steel weight, hose pump and the steel parts of the nozzle was not grounded. Static electricity probably accumulated on these parts and caused a spark and ignited the whole thing
Static electricity is formed when liquid flows through pipes, valves and other equipment
Correct bonding and grounding ensures that static electricity does not accumulate and cause a spark
Static sparks can ignite many flammable vapour air mixtures
Bonding refers to connecting materials to make sure they're same electrical potential
Grounding refers to connecting the material to a 0 potential. The earth, we consider as 0 potential


Ensure conductive piping is properly bonded and grounded. and properly designed for flammable service
When carrying out tasks, ensure as little free fall as possible to prevent sparks

A few hundred years ago, when the entropy equation didn't exist, people were trying to convert all the heat into work because of the industrial revolution and they wanted MAXIMUM work from heat. They were trying to devise motors or engines.

Class D fires - Caused by combustible metals

for class A fires

There are two approaches for pressure drop through fittings
one is using the fanning friction factor
fanning friction factor is a function of reynold's number, but then for fittings how do you know the reynolds number? what is the diameter of a valve? It's difficult to imagine, You end up using the reynold's number of the pipe fitted on the fitting and you get the equivalent length of the fitting and use the equation:

In the L_e/D approach (equivalent length approach), a reported literature value of L_E/D is selected. Multiply this value by the diameter of the pipe in which the fitting is involved to get equivalent length.
Equivalent pipe is the same length of straight pipe required to have the same pressure drop Underlining everything is underlining nothing - M.M. Sharma
Other approach is the head coefficient approach


The first part is the head loss coefficient and is denoted by K:

This is called number of velocity head approach
Darcy friction factor is 4 times fanning friction factor. This is because he was french and everyone hates the french.
When flow dividing or flow merging is required you need a T joint
Non return swing check valves have a service life and should be services regularly It is criminal to use square elbows - AVP sir

wp is work of pump per unit volume
theres also alpha at the velocity heads that is multiplied. I don't know what it stands for

What is suction head? When there is no movement, there is P_1 and P_2 at the two points because of possibly height difference
P_1 and H_1 exist regardless of flow, but if the pump is not on, the v_1 is 0 We are talking about inherently failproof design.
There is no suction in centrifugal pumps, but in reciprocating pumps, there is a suction power. This is why the centrifugal pump needs a little head value to get going. Tldr Centrifugal pump just sucks at sucking and thus needs a little energy to get the fluid to keep the suction side flooded. This is not a problem with reciprocating pumps because they're better at sucking (in all areas, theyre just bad pumps and they make so much noise)
We must subtract vapour pressure from the suction head to get the net positive suction head. This is because the vapour potential head is negligible so we do a vapour correction. This net positive suction head must be more than 0. The vapour be eating into our head cus del h has gas density negligible so it becomes P+rho g (h-hgas) hgas comes from bubble formation
We subtract to remove any remote possibility of the suction head suffering from the vapour pressure. MINUS DA FRICTIONAL LOSSES ALSO BROO The suction head cannot suffer!!
net positive suction head for bigger pumps is 7-10 meters and for smaller pumps it's 3-4 meters.
NPSH has nothing to do with the delivery side which is the RHS
When you buy a pump, they give a rating for the pump discharge which is the head for any fluid, not just water
Example It is proposed to pump 10,000kg/hr of toluene at 114 C and 1.1atm absolute pressure from the reboiler of a distillation column of a second distillation unit without cooling the toluene before it enters the pump. If the friction loss in the line between the reboiler and pump is 7kN/m^2 and the density of toluene is 866 KG/M3, how far above the pump must be the liquid level in the reboiler be maintained to give a net positive suction head of 2.5m

reboiler is boiling point and if the toluene is boiling there and thus the vapour pressure is 1.1atm

item.title: Intro to chemical analysis
item.description:
Introduction to chemical analysis, terminology (technique,method, procedure, protocol), broad classification of analytical techniques, good laboratory practices

Analytical chemistry is the qualitative and quantitative characterization of matter


Technique is any chemical or physical principle we can use to study an analyte
Basically the phenomenon you use to form a method
A method is the application of a technique for a specific analyte in a specific matrix
So this is like the intrument
A procedure is a set of written directions telling us how to apply a method to a particular sample, including information on obtaining samples, handling interferents, and validating results
Nerdshit
Example in pca
Technique -> You can use your eyes to see colour
Method -> you look at the piss to see if yellow when using a urinal

item.title: Lab safety
item.description:
#safety
In India, life is cheap
#safety

Main routes of entry of the chemicals into the human body are: Inhalation into the lungs, Absorption through skin, Ingestion
Chemical safety and Chemical security are two important aspects of lab safety
Chemical safety is to protect people from chemicals
Chemical security is to protect chemicals from bad people



Examples are: sulfuric acid, nitric acid, potassium hydroxide
Corrosive substances cause destructive burns on the tissue by chemical action at the site of contact
Corrosive effect can also happen in respiratory tract or gastrointestinal tract



Examples - hydrogen peroxide, nitric acid, perchloric acid, etc.
They readily decompose under certain conditions to yield oxygen
They can cause a fire to burn violently
Oxidisers musn't be stored with flammables



These readily catch fire and burn in air
The vapours released from a flammable liquid are a common fire hazard in a laboratory
The degree of hazard associated with a flammable liquid depends on it's flash point, flammability limit and ignition temperature



When subjected to heat, impact or friction, undergoes a rapid chemical change evolving large volumes of gases which cause a sudden increase in pressure
Examples - acetylides, azides, nitrogen triiodide, organic peroxides
perchloric acid if allowed to dry on wood or other combustibles,will explode and cause a fire on impact or friction
picric acid and picrates are detonated by heat and impact


LD50 - lethal dosage 50 milligrams
Toxic chemicals produce injurious or lethal effects upon contact with body cells due to their chemical properties



same sign as flammable
The rapid oxidation of a pyrophoric chemical by oxygen or moisture in the air causes the compound to ignite spontaneously

These chemicals react violentl when they come in contact with water

Examples - lithium, sodium, potassium, aluminium, etc


always order the smallest quantity of chemical.
The risk of an event occurring reduces
Where possible, purchase a less hazardous chemical



Received packages must be checked to ensure that the containers arein good condition
Details of new chemicals must be entered in the lab inventory
The date of receipt and date of first usage should be recorded for shelf life calculation
Ensure the MSDS is obtained with the chemical and is readily available for reference


Bulk stocks must be stored in a separate building
A spill or fire involving bulk containers will be difficult to tackle
Chemicals must be grouped according to their properties

Oxidisers, flammables, acids, bases, reproductive toxins and carcinogens are all to be stored separately
Keep shelves at max height 1.5 meters so short people don't burn down the building. Fix the shelf to the wall to prevent it's fall
Store heavier bottles lower The japanese are very disciplined people. Look at five S
USE lab purpose fridges


chemical formulae or short forms must not be used to label.
Labels must include the hazard and brief description of it


Chemical spill kits
PPE
Scoops and dustpans
Dry Sand


examine inventory annually
safety is good
don't burn down the lab
dont be a foolish fellow

item.title: Machine Safety
item.description:
#safety
#safety Unguarded moving parts of machines and the sudden or uncontrolled release of their power systems can result in serious injuries


Loose clothing, hair, jewelry
Materials ejected from the machine when it is operational
Inadvertent starting of the machine
slipping and falling into a place
Contact with sharp edges
Making adjustments while the machine is operational
Unauthorized operation of machine
Lack of preventative maintenance


Rotating gears
Belt and pulley
Chain and sprocket
Between the grinding wheel and tool rest
Between rotating and fixed parts
Machines alone:
Shafts, couplings
A nip point is a dangerous part of a machinery


Any machine part which can cause injury must be guarded
Fixed guard - doesnt move, kept in place permanently by fasteners
Interlocked Guard - Shuts off or disengages power to the machine and prevents it from starting when the guard is removed or opened
Adjustable Guard - Provides a barrier which can be adjusted to suit the varying sizes of the input stock
Self adjusting guard - Provides a barrier which moves according to the size of the stock entering the danger site (?)
Pull back device - The device is attached to the wrist of the operator which pulls the operators hand away from the point of operation
Two hand control - used so that people are forced to use both hands so they don't multitask


Shields can be used to provide protection from flying particles
Holding tools can be used to place and remove stock instead of having to use your hand in a danger area


Ensure that the guards are in position and in good working order when working
Didn't catch the rest
Keys and adjusting wrenches must be removed from the machine before operating it
Stop the machine before measuring, cleaning or making any adjustments
Do not handle metal turnings by hand as they can cause injury. Use brush or rake to remove turning
Keep hands away from the cutting head and all moving parts
Cutting tools must be clean and sharp
Avoid awkward operations and hand positions
Keep work area clean. Floor must be level and have a non slip surface
There must be enough space around the machine to do the job safely
The person working with the machine must not be distracted
Machines must not be unattended. Switch it off
Rotating parts must not be stopped with hands
Compressed air must not be used to clean machines as this can force small particles to fly off and can cause injury to the eyes


Safety glasses must be used when working with dangerous stuff
Safety glasses must be work by all personnel entering an area thats dangerous
Ear protection must be work for protection from high noise
Hand gloves must NOT be used while working with machines, due to the changes of getting caught at nip point Note - say this to tinkerers lab
When making deep holes, make sure the hole is clean properly
Lubricate the drill bit before drilling a hole
Reduce the drilling pressure when the drill begins to break through the material
DO NOT force the drill with extra pressure
Centre the drill work deeply enough to provide support for the piece while it's turning
Secure and clamp the piece while it's being worked
Guard must be provided to the chuck
Inspect chuck for wear or damage
Remove the chuck wrench immediately after adjusting the chuck
Holding the work incorrectly (grinding machine problems)
Grinding on the side of the wheel is badd
Using the wrong type of wheel or disk

Lockout - tagout or lock and tag is a system used to ensure that machines are properly shut off and not started up again before the completion of maintenance or servicing work.
Hazardous power sources must be isolated before repair can be started

item.title: Non ideal flow
item.description:
Difficult but rewarding
While we can describe reactors as ideal plug flow, ideal backmix or ideal batch reactors, in reality, none of the reactors at large scale follow these equations well. This is due to short circuiting and recycling of fluid

Great idea in general but how does an RTD have anything to do with non ideal flows in reactors???

, theta is simply the dimensionless time in terms of spacetime of the reactor
The internal age distribution of the contents of the reactor is denoted by I
“Pasted image 20240621004336.png” could not be found.
Exit age distribution is a distribution of residence times of fluid in the reactor


These are all done using stimulus response techniques, where we add a stimulus in the reactor and see how the system responds to it


When a step tracer is added to the reactor

It slowly increases from 0 to one

To get the conversion, simply get the conversion as a function for spacetime and integrate it over the distribution


“Pasted image 20240621225105.png” could not be found.
This is for packed bed and tubular reactors (plug flow basically)
The idea here is that there is diffusive mass transfer that occurs between any slice of fluid in the plug flow and the rest of the fluid axially in front and behind it
Fick's law of diffusion:
Peclet number measures the intensity of dispersion, with it being 0 for ideal plug flow and infinity for ideal backmix
The C or F curve can be converted to a theoretical curve by fitting to the data and the relationship between standard deviation, mean of and D/uL is given by a set of equations found by Levenspiel the greatest human himself around page 266 of his stellar book, Chemical Reaction Engineering
This kind of data analysis to get peclet number is usually done using a pulse tracer input. A pulse input manytimes causes flow disturbances at it's point of entry and to correct for this, readings are taken at two downstream points and the delta of the two points is taken for standard deviations and all
The formulae for getting the peclet number from these deltas are also given in levenspiel
When they give bed porosity and such, its to calculate the space time of the reactor so we can get the dimensionless units which are used to get peclet number and all
The first part is accounting for bulk flow, The second for diffusive mass transfer and third for reactive dissapearance“Pasted image 20240621235412.png” could not be found.“Pasted image 20240621235423.png” could not be found.

Recycle flow - when a portion of fluid leaving a flow region is recycled back into in

item.description:
#polymers
#polymers
The trickiest thing about polymerization isn't initiation or propagation but termination

wood is a composite of cellulose and lignin - polyphenolic compound. Lignin binds the cellulose


Emulsion polymerization - used where two phases are immiscible, polymer formed is in a single phase. The substance used to bind the phases is called an emulsifier. Emulsifiers are used to match the surface energy of the two phases. Acrylic emulsions are in pharma, paints and cosmetics.
Solution polymerization -
Suspension polymerization
Bulk polymerization


The most basic requirement of polymerization is that each monomer must have a functionality greater than 2
Functionality is the number of bonds it can make with other functional groups of other monomers
Carothers classified polymerization reactions into addition polymerization and condensation polymerization. This classification isn't in use anymore as there was some overlap between the two
The method of classifying polymerization reactions is in step growth and chain growth polymerizations
Step growth polymerizations are characterized by a high rate of reaction at the start, levelling out later. For these polymerizations, high extent of reactions (of the functional groups) are required for high chain lengths
Chain growth polymerizations have a constant rate of reaction from start to end

item.description:
#polymers
Tip These are my notes from Introduction to Polymers, Robert J. Young and college classes
#polymers
Quote “So once you do know what the question actually is, you'll know what the answer means.”

A polymer is a substance composed of long sequences of one or more species of atoms or groups of atoms linked together by primary, usually covalent bonds
In simple words, they're substances made up of big, BIG molecules
They're also called macromolecules and are created by a process of linking together smaller molecules called monomers
They're really useful because they're lightweight
Usually two plastics are mixed to make blends to make one with exactly the properties one wants
PET - poly(ethylene terepthalate) is a blend of PE and PT

blends differ from composites in the sense that composites have one material that is reinforcing mechanically
both blends and composites are binary phase mix


1820 -> This guy, Thomas Hancock, found a way to blend additives to rubber (a natural polymer) by beating it up (masticating it)
1839 -> Charles Goodyear added sulphur to rubber and found it got stronger. This process was named vulcanization.
1846 - 1870 -> Some guy prepared nitrocellulose, sold it as an explosive. Another guy thought to mold it and make items out of it as it was found it be a hard elastic material that is also soluble and easily mold-able. Two other guys thought it would be smart to do this with something that isn't an explosive - celluloid. Instant commercial success.
1892 -> Cross, Bevan and Beadle patented the viscose process for dissolving and regenerating cellulose
1920s -> This absolute chad of a human, Hermann Staudinger studied the synthesis, structure and properties of polyoxymethylene and polystyrene to give emprical evidence of his idea that polymers are really just macromolecules containing large sequences of monomers. Everyone doubted him, but the haters were proven wrong

item.title: Processing
item.description:
#polymers
#polymers

You process a polymer at it's processing temperature. In case of polymers the processing temperature is above it's melting temperature
To reduce the resistance of the material, you need to increase the temperature above the melt temperature to reduce viscosity. Generally about 10C higher than melting point
Polymer processing is done for application, study of properties and to reduce the cost of a compound by adding a filler or use a cheaper material along with the polymer
First part of processing is called dry blending then melt blending. Not strictly a requirement


Dry blending - You don't allow the polymer to melt when processing. Example - you have one powder phase and one pellet/granular phase and they're just mixed up. Can't be regularly agitated since the powder will separate from the granules due to difference in density. Oily phase to be added to the mixture so the powder is tied to the granules. The oily phase is called a wetting agent and that causes adsorption/ soaking of the powder on the granule.
The granules are added then wetting agent then powder at the end. The wetting agent isn't added in the end because this would cause the powder to be clumped up together
When you're mixing in a tumbler, the rpm you choose is important. The optimized speed is a problem. The RPM where you're getting a constant bulk density is the optimum speed

To know when something is properly mixed you sample and check the bulk density. The bulk density is measured using a British cylinder
Melt blending - Melt 'n Mix after making a uniform dry blend as written above. It's not mandatory all the time to have dry then melt processing, you can go directly to melt by using feeders.


Extrusion is a continuous output with positive displacement.
An air pump is not an extruder since it retracts and this it is not continuous
A screw is used to extrude polymer to have a continuous positive displacement

To increase the mixing, you must reduce the distance between the screw and the barrel. This has the consequence of reducing the mass flow
Should the shear profile be constant or profile(non constant) through the extrusion? It shouldn't because it wouldnt be mixed properly if it was

item.title: solution to question 1
item.description:
Problem A biotechnology manufacturing firm can produce diagnostic testing kits at a cost if $20. Each kit for which there is a demandin the week ofproduction can be sold for $100. However, the half-life of components requires the kti to be scrapped if not used within a week. The cost of scrapping a kit is $5. The weekly demand can be summarized as follows:
0(units demanded) - 0.05 (probability)
50 - 0.4
100 - 0.3
200 - 0.25 How many kits should be sold to maximise the mean earnings of the company?
Let x be the number of units created in a certain week
we need to maximize the earnings, thus, we can plot their mean earnings for a certain number of kits produced
mean Profits if 200>x>=100:

mean Profits if 100>x>=50:

mean Profits if 50>x>=0:

This is a classic case of linear programming:

we can see that the maximum mean earnings occur at 200 kits produced no matter what the demand is for a certain week
if we change the probability of demand being 200 from 0.25 to 0.05 and increasing the probability for 50 to 0.6, the following graph appears showing 50 to be the optimal number of kits produced



Dependencies - numpy, matplotlib, python 3.5
import numpy as np import matplotlib.pyplot as plt def gothru(x,p1,p2,p3,p4): if 200>=x>=100: return p1*(x*80)+p2*(100*80-25*(x-100))+p3*(50*80-25*(x-50))+p4*(-25*x) elif 100>x>=50: return p1*(x*80)+p2*(100*80)+p3*(50*80-25*(x-50))+p4*(-25*x) elif 50>x: return p1*(x*80)+p2*(100*80)+p3*(50*80)+p4*(-25*x) x = np.linspace(0,200,100) y = [] for i in x: y.append(gothru(i,0.25,0.3,0.4,0.05)) y = np.array(y) plt.plot(x,y) plt.xlabel("units produced") plt.ylabel("profits") plt.show() Copy

Engineering, Specialty polymers and commodity polymers
commodity polymers are used in day to day usage
Engineering polymers used in engineering applications on the basis of application
Specialty polymers used in niche applications like aerospace or aviation
ON the basis of chemical nature is thermoplastic and thermoset
to classify a polymer you must use it's nature, occurrence and application
example - PET is a commodity thermoplastic synthetic material
blends are binary mixtures of polymers. composites are binary mixtures used in reinforcement systems, blends are all other mixtures, filled plastics are also binary phases
composites are only for mechanical properties
filled plastics - when you put in a filler, pigment



You have the linear skeletal polymers which are just chains with two ends
Cyclic Polymers - are chains with no ends
Branched Polymers - Have side chains that are branches to the main chain at branch points
Network Polymers - Have a 3D structure in which each chain is connected to many others. Such a polymers is also called crosslinked
differences in the skeletal structure have massive implications on the physical properties of polymers, even with the same base monomers



Based on the identities of the monomers making up the polymer, we classify them as homopolymers and copolymers
Homopolymers are made up of a single repeating unit and are represented by where A is the repeating unit. The proper way to name these is to use 'poly' then write the chemical name for the repeating unit
Copolymers - Made up of many different monomers. Naming and all will be detailed in a separate page. There are statistical, alternating, block and many other different types of copolymers



The classification most people use when speaking about polymers is of them divided into - thermoplastics, elastomers and thermosets
Thermoplastics are linear of branched polymers which become liquid upon application of heat. They can be moulded and remoulded into any shape. They do not crystallise easily. Many of these are amorphous - not crystalline - and are characterized by their glass transition temperature, at which they move between glassy and rubbery states. Can be remoulded multiple times
Elastomers are crosslinked polymers that are rubbery. They aren't called rubber since that word is for rubbery polymers that arent crosslinked. Elastomers are characterised by their capability to be stretched into large lengths and return to their original state. These are thermoplastics
Thermoset polymers are polymers that cant be remoulded or melted. They have very high degrees of crosslinking. Eg rubber after vulcanisation


they are black because of carbon black which is added in the rubber
the black causes a higher frictional factor
the carbon black is very conductive - its good at dissipating the frictional (adiabatic) heat that is transferred into the tyre
the black causes good weather resistance - weatherability. Good resistance toward UV


Dyes are medium (example: water) soluble, pigments are not soluble in mediums
Pigments are used in polymer engineering


solutions cause the solute and solvent to be in a single phase
dispersion is a state of mixture when the substances won't settle or float(go up or down)
emulsion is a state of mixture when it's added binary phase but becomes single phase with surface tension effects this section to be updated

A-B-C
if we suppose the above is a representation of a molecule, B is the compatible-izer since it causes a link between A and C to occur. Without B, this would have not happened. It makes A and C compatible
This is for any system.
In polymerization reactions, catalysts are used as compatiblizers


Viscosity is the resistance to flow
Materials that thin when you shear them, are non newtonian (viscosity reduces with shear). Polymers are non newtonian
Since they thin when we add shear, it's more processable
it's a function of temperature and pressure. Any change in either of these variables will cause a change in viscosity

I need kreyzig because I don't want to remember variable separable solution of differential equations. Honestly I like them solved numerically but an analytic understanding of the world is sometimes fun. forget it, solve this yourself.

Why is it unsteady? - because the temperature profile changes with time until it becomes linear
Why won't a linear temperature profile change with time? - Take a really thin slice of a slab with a Delta T temperature difference. The heat flux across this slab will no doubt be dependant on Delta T divided by the thickness of the slab. Now take every slab before it, if the Delta T is the same across the same thickness in every single slab -> the heat flux will be the same, no heat gets left over, no heat gets snatched away. The temperature profile is unaffected.
I know the above isn't really a proof because it is dependent on itself but it's a neat explanation

item.title: Water Pollution
item.description:
#Environment
#Environment
Quote "Life is too depressing to make up more of it" - Marvin
ESG - Environmental, Social and Governance

In the 80s, under LPG (liberalization, privatization and globalization) caused India to stop being a closed economy. Now we are entering ESG.
Point source - Industrial Facilities, Municipal Waste Water Treatment Plants
Nonpoint source - Agricultural runoff, Construction sites, Storm drainage Any activity where corruption happens is unsustainable. After the right to information act, corruption stopped happening
Biodegradation
Amount of perturbation that an ecosystem can absorb - Resistance
The rate at which the ecosystem recovers from perturbation - Resilience
RSPM - Respirable Suspended Particulate Matter
SPM - Suspended particulate matter
IN US, the regulators are USEPA, and in india idk
BOD<30
COD<100
Missing Wouldn't the more obvious logic be that if a country is rich, then the pollution will be less right? - Me

Debris from construction sites
Coal in india has a lot of ash content and this can be solved by adding coal washeries which is an example of coal benefication. That coal now has a higher calorific value and less residue when burnt
I wrote everything but in the wrong areas so beware ig


Every industry must have a fishtank for their water waste to make sure the BOD and COD isn't too high. The fish must survive for 48 hours
These substances will lower the oxygen content
Lakes - there is a source of phosphorous and nitrogen that causes certain algae and hyacinth to grow and thats an indicator if high COD. This causes eutrophication.
Any stream that is hot, causes oxygen solubility to go down. Oxygen solubility is inversely proportional to temperature
Agricultural waste
Pollution from petroleum products. They float on the water
You can skim off the oil on the surface and decant it to recycle oil back into the refinery and to save the water from being polluted







Need to have a relook at storm drains


We use a lot of fertilizers and the uptake rate of these fertilizers isn't enough to prevent runoff.



When you mine the ore, you gotta solubilize it in acid. Bauxite ore, byproduct is red mud when refining it. Red mud contains iron oxide, silica, rare earth metals and titanium. Titanium is pretty useful.Biggest challenge for chemical engineers - get into red mud valorization(value addition).
Red mud is highly basic in nature and the rainwater percolates through it. Problem. This causes irreparable damage. Alkalosilic bacteria begins to develop. The ba>A non apple device has this for 33% charge and an apple device has the same icon for 10%...cteria convert the base into acid, which causes a bunch of issues and the ecosystem is in a good bit of trouble. Also red mud has iron, which is not good to have in drinking water
The solid waste can be reclaimed using hydrometallurgy and pyrometallurgy
The chloralkali industry - india has 48 plants. This produces chlorine and no one wants any of it. People want caustic soda though. Major use of chlorine is in PVC,which is high in demand. We are importing a lot of PVC. We should be having a choralkali industry near a PVC manufacturing plant
Fly ash - used in construction of bricks and cement additive (mandated by the law). NO unburnt carbon can be there. Weird The main product in a sulfuric acid plant is power


Bad stuff
MIDC
Biggest agricultural chemical zone in india is in ankileshwar.
PCPIR - Petrochemical and petroleum industry region
4 R's - Reduce, Reuse, Recycle, Reprocess
REFUSE - related to dumping - when you don't think it can be reused or anything
When fire breaks out in dumps, it happens because of methanation. Methane is produced due to biodegradable products breaking down and finding a spark. This is why these dumps are well ventilated Important Find out waste that isn't yet
Chemical industries are invariably going to produce waste
In environmental science we now talk about atom efficiency - processes in which yield and conversion both are pretty high. The trend here is in catalytic reactions not homogeneous reactions so at the source the amount of pollutants are minimized
